title: 108_hr1165
content:
The Act is titled the "National Computer Recycling Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The "National Computer Recycling Act" defines key terms such as Administrator, cathode ray tube, central processing unit, and computer. The "National Computer Recycling Act" defines key terms including hazardous waste, monitor, and nonprofit organization. The "National Computer Recycling Act" defines key terms including hazardous waste, monitor, and nonprofit organization. SEC. 3. FEE. The Administrator will require a fee on the sale of designated electronic devices to cover specific costs, with uniform amounts for devices with integrated central processing units and monitors. The Administrator will require a fee on the sale of designated electronic devices, not exceeding $10 per device, with exemptions for used devices and administrative costs covered by a 3 percent retention. The Administrator may exempt certain sales from a fee if they promote maximum reuse and environmentally responsible disposal of electronic devices no longer in use. Additional electronic devices may be designated for the fee if they contain hazardous waste materials. The Administrator may exempt certain sales from a fee if they promote maximum reuse and environmentally responsible disposal of electronic devices no longer in use. Additional electronic devices may be designated for the fee if they contain hazardous waste materials, such as liquid crystal displays, cathode ray tubes, or circuit boards. "SEC. 4. GRANTS." The Administrator uses fee amounts collected under section 3 for administration costs and grants. Grants are given for collecting, processing, reusing, and extracting materials from used computers and devices. Grants are available for individuals or organizations to collect, process, and reuse materials from used computers and devices. Eligibility requires compliance with environmental and health laws. Selection criteria include diverting items from landfills, cost per unit, market potential for recycled materials, and environmental impact mitigation. The Administrator ensures grants are given to a diverse group of recipients. The selection criteria include innovative recycling technologies and a history of environmentally responsible disposal of computers and devices. SEC. 5. CONSULTATION.

The Administrator will consult with representatives from various industries and organizations, including computer manufacturing, retail, recycling, waste management, environmental and consumer groups, and local government units.

SEC. 6. STUDY AND REPORTS. The Administrator will conduct a study to identify hazardous waste materials in used computers, estimate quantities of these materials, assess costs of transportation and processing, describe current waste management practices, make recommendations for end-of-life management of electronic products, and estimate demand for recycled materials. The Administrator will conduct a study on hazardous waste materials in used computers, estimate quantities, assess costs, describe current practices, make recommendations for end-of-life management, and estimate demand for recycled materials. Reports on computer recycling status, fees collected, administrative costs, and grants will be transmitted to Congress annually for 5 years.
